board.name: power
board.test: 1) Insert 15A (Blue) fuse into lower slot. 2) Insert 1A (Black) fuse into slot on the rear of the board. 3) Plug in power switch. 4) Connect 12V to the battery input. 5) Close power switch. Result: Should draw around ???mA.
Check that the '3V3' LED is on.
1) Open power switch. 2) Conncet UIF. 3) Close power switch. 4) Program MSP. 5) Run code. Result: Code runs.
1) Open power switch. 2) Hold down the two buttons to the lower right of the screen. 3) Close power switch. Result: Tune plays through piezo. CHARGE, debug(SRIC activity) and motor rail LEDs flash.
Press each button in turn, an LED should toggle. Press/turn rotary encoders, more LEDs should toggle.
Measure the voltage on the motor rail. Should be toggling between 0 and 12V.
Load the motor rail, preferably with 60W or more. Nothing should break, load should turn on/off.
1) Open power switch. 2) Close power switch. Result: 5V LED should turn on. 5V rail should be 5V.
Measure the voltage on the USB hub power socket. Should be 5V.

1) Open power switch. 2) Disconnect 12V from the battery input. 3) Mount BeagleBoard. 4) Connect 12V to the battery input. 5) Close power switch. Result: Should draw around ??mA. After 3 seconds backlight should illuminate.

Check each user LED on the slug using the following python code: from sr import * import time for x in range(0,4): power.led[x] = 1 time.sleep(1) power.led[x] = 0 time.sleep(1)
Check that each light flashes in turn.
Talk to and power another (known-working) board through all the RJ11 connectors.
